title: Aviation Industry Corporation of China provides sewage cleaning assistance to Zambia's Ministry of Local Government and Rural
description: On October 27, 2021, the Aviation Industry Corporation of China aided Zambia's Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development in cleaning up drainages in Zambia's capital Lusaka. The sewage cleaning was conducted in both central business areas and residential areas. The purpose of this project is to help avoid flooding in Zambia during the upcoming rainy season and is a part of the company's social responsibility initiative.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
Aviation Industry Corporation of China provides sewage cleaning assistance to Zambia's Ministry of Local Government and Rural

# Description
On October 27, 2021, the Aviation Industry Corporation of China aided Zambia's Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development in cleaning up drainages in Zambia's capital Lusaka. The sewage cleaning was conducted in both central business areas and residential areas. The purpose of this project is to help avoid flooding in Zambia during the upcoming rainy season and is a part of the company's social responsibility initiative.
justification: Project focuses on sewage cleaning and flood prevention as part of social responsibility, with no direct energy or environmental transition impact
evidence: Sewage cleaning in urban areas, flood prevention focus, social responsibility initiative

title: Jilin Province of China provides 30,000 masks to University of Zambia in June 2021 (Linked to Project ID#92881)
description: On June 4, 2021, the Jilin Province of China and the Chinese Embassy jointly donated medical masks to the University of Zambia. The total number of masks provided was 50,000. The Jilin Province provided 30,000 masks while the Chinese Embassy provided 20,000 masks. These masks will be used to improve COVID-19 response efforts by the University of Zambia, the largest public university in the country. Masks will be distributed among students and faculty in the university. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lusaka, Zambia. Li Jie, China’s Ambassador to Zambia, and Professor Luke Mumba, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Zambia, attended the ceremony. Chinese and Zambian directors of the Confucius Institute at the University of Zambia also attended the ceremony.  The Chinese Embassy's contribution to this donation is captured in Project ID#92881.
staff_comments: 1. Because the Jilin Province of China contributed 30,000 masks for this donation, AidData used the unit supply amount of face masks to estimate a monetary value of $10,020.00 USD.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

# Description
On June 4, 2021, the Jilin Province of China and the Chinese Embassy jointly donated medical masks to the University of Zambia. The total number of masks provided was 50,000. The Jilin Province provided 30,000 masks while the Chinese Embassy provided 20,000 masks. These masks will be used to improve COVID-19 response efforts by the University of Zambia, the largest public university in the country. Masks will be distributed among students and faculty in the university. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lusaka, Zambia. Li Jie, China’s Ambassador to Zambia, and Professor Luke Mumba, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Zambia, attended the ceremony. Chinese and Zambian directors of the Confucius Institute at the University of Zambia also attended the ceremony.  The Chinese Embassy's contribution to this donation is captured in Project ID#92881.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for COVID-19 response, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of 50,000 medical masks to University of Zambia for COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Government provides loan for Kunzvi Dam Project
description: The Kunzvi Dam Project involves the construction of a dam at confluence of the Nora and Nyagui rivers in Goromonzi District, the laying of a pipeline connecting the dam to the northern and eastern suburbs of Harare, and the construction of a water treatment plant. In November 2005, Zimbabwe’s Vice President Joice Mujuru and Water Resources and Infrastructure Development Minister Munacho Mutezo signed an agreement with China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd (CJIC). CJIC agreed in principal to build the Kunzvi Dam and provide irrigation equipment to boost food security in exchange for mineral concessions; however, the project did not move forward, leaving many urban areas without regular water supply. Then, in 2013, Kunzvi Water Development Corporation — a special purpose vehicle — was appointed to implement the project on a build, own, operate, and transfer (BOOT) basis. At that time, Vinci of France and Group Five of South Africa were announced as the major project contractors. However, after the project stalled again, the Government of Zimbabwe signed an RMB 3.962 billion ($680 million) commercial (EPC) contract with Power China International (中国电建国际公司) for Phase 1 of the Kunzwi Dam Project on July 28, 2016. Then, in November 2016, Sinohydro was appointed to implement the first phase of the project on a build, own, operate, and transfer (BOOT) basis.    In a 2018 meeting in Beijing with President Mnangagwa, President Xi Jinping, pledged financial support for the Kunzvi Dam Project. During the same year, President Mnangagwa announced that he had secured funding for the project. A feasibility study was undertaken in 2019. The project was also allocated $259 million by Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube in the 2020 National Budget. However, in 2020, reports emerged that the Government of Zimbabwe had failed to pay both the loan management/commitment fees and Sinosure credit insurance premium needed to facilitate the implementation of the project. This outcome ‘greatly frustrated’ Sinosure. Then, in 2021, a new tendering process was initiated by the Government of Zimbabwe and China Nanchang Engineering (Pvt) Ltd was awarded a $109 million contract to build the dam on a build, operate and transfer (BOT) basis. In August 2021, China Daily — an English-language daily newspaper owned by the Central Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party — reported that '[t]he dam is being built through a loan from China.' During the same month, Taurai Maurikira, the chief executive of the Zimbabwe National Water Authority, told a local newspaper (Sunday Mail) that following a recent site handover, China Nanchang Engineering (Pvt) Ltd had moved on site to start work on the water reservoir. An official project commencement ceremony took place in December 2021. The project was, at that time, expected to reach completion by January 2024. Two months later, in February 2022, Zimbabwe National Water Authority (Zinwa) and the Ministry of Local Government and Public Works were on the ground identifying families affected upstream by the project. Then, in March 2022, Mr Liangming Jin, executive chairman of China Nanchang Engineering (Pvt) Ltd, stated that additional equipment had arrived in Beira and was being dispatched to the Kunzvi dam project site. Heavy construction equipment, such as excavators, bulldozers, and tippers, had already arrived on site.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Kunzvi-Musami-Harare Water Project. The Chinese project title is 昆兹维大坝—哈拉雷供水项目 or 昆兹维大坝工程. 2. The face value of the loan is unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes that that the face value of the loan is equivalent to 85% ($92.65 million) of the total project cost ($109 million). This issue merits further investigation. 3. The identify of the Chinese lender is unknown. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides loan for Kunzvi Dam Project

# Description
The Kunzvi Dam Project involves the construction of a dam at confluence of the Nora and Nyagui rivers in Goromonzi District, the laying of a pipeline connecting the dam to the northern and eastern suburbs of Harare, and the construction of a water treatment plant. In November 2005, Zimbabwe’s Vice President Joice Mujuru and Water Resources and Infrastructure Development Minister Munacho Mutezo signed an agreement with China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd (CJIC). CJIC agreed in principal to build the Kunzvi Dam and provide irrigation equipment to boost food security in exchange for mineral concessions; however, the project did not move forward, leaving many urban areas without regular water supply. Then, in 2013, Kunzvi Water Development Corporation — a special purpose vehicle — was appointed to implement the project on a build, own, operate, and transfer (BOOT) basis. At that time, Vinci of France and Group Five of South Africa were announced as the major project contractors. However, after the project stalled again, the Government of Zimbabwe signed an RMB 3.962 billion ($680 million) commercial (EPC) contract with Power China International (中国电建国际公司) for Phase 1 of the Kunzwi Dam Project on July 28, 2016. Then, in November 2016, Sinohydro was appointed to implement the first phase of the project on a build, own, operate, and transfer (BOOT) basis.    In a 2018 meeting in Beijing with President Mnangagwa, President Xi Jinping, pledged financial support for the Kunzvi Dam Project. During the same year, President Mnangagwa announced that he had secured funding for the project. A feasibility study was undertaken in 2019. The project was also allocated $259 million by Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube in the 2020 National Budget. However, in 2020, reports emerged that the Government of Zimbabwe had failed to pay both the loan management/commitment fees and Sinosure credit insurance premium needed to facilitate the implementation of the project. This outcome ‘greatly frustrated’ Sinosure. Then, in 2021, a new tendering process was initiated by the Government of Zimbabwe and China Nanchang Engineering (Pvt) Ltd was awarded a $109 million contract to build the dam on a build, operate and transfer (BOT) basis. In August 2021, China Daily — an English-language daily newspaper owned by the Central Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party — reported that '[t]he dam is being built through a loan from China.' During the same month, Taurai Maurikira, the chief executive of the Zimbabwe National Water Authority, told a local newspaper (Sunday Mail) that following a recent site handover, China Nanchang Engineering (Pvt) Ltd had moved on site to start work on the water reservoir. An official project commencement ceremony took place in December 2021. The project was, at that time, expected to reach completion by January 2024. Two months later, in February 2022, Zimbabwe National Water Authority (Zinwa) and the Ministry of Local Government and Public Works were on the ground identifying families affected upstream by the project. Then, in March 2022, Mr Liangming Jin, executive chairman of China Nanchang Engineering (Pvt) Ltd, stated that additional equipment had arrived in Beira and was being dispatched to the Kunzvi dam project site. Heavy construction equipment, such as excavators, bulldozers, and tippers, had already arrived on site.
justification: The project primarily focuses on water supply infrastructure, which is not directly related to energy transition or environmental impact
evidence: Construction of dam, water treatment plant, and pipeline for water supply and irrigation purposes

title: Chinese Government builds wells in Zimbabwe in 2021
description: In  2021, the Chinese Government funded the construction of an unknown amount of water wells across Zimbabwe, contracted to and implemented by the Chinese corporation Jiangxi International Corporation. These wells are often referred to in Chinese and Zimbabwean reports as the "Chinese Wells". At least 1,000 Chinese-aided wells have been constructed in Zimbabwe since 2012, with the "Chinese Wells" initiative in Zimbabwe ending in 2021.   The sites receiving these wells included Esgordini Regional Hospital (completed in July 2021), Rumene Village, Senondo Primary School (completed in August 2021), and 27 wells in Zipingo District (completed in September 2021). In December, China and Zimbabwe held a video conference on the completion and acceptance of the aided well drilling project in Zimbabwe.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is '援津巴布韦打井项目'.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
Chinese Government builds wells in Zimbabwe in 2021

# Description
In  2021, the Chinese Government funded the construction of an unknown amount of water wells across Zimbabwe, contracted to and implemented by the Chinese corporation Jiangxi International Corporation. These wells are often referred to in Chinese and Zimbabwean reports as the "Chinese Wells". At least 1,000 Chinese-aided wells have been constructed in Zimbabwe since 2012, with the "Chinese Wells" initiative in Zimbabwe ending in 2021.   The sites receiving these wells included Esgordini Regional Hospital (completed in July 2021), Rumene Village, Senondo Primary School (completed in August 2021), and 27 wells in Zipingo District (completed in September 2021). In December, China and Zimbabwe held a video conference on the completion and acceptance of the aided well drilling project in Zimbabwe.
justification: Project focuses on water supply infrastructure for communities and institutions, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Construction of water wells across Zimbabwe, including at hospitals, schools, and villages

title: Chinese Embassy donates supplies worth $2,300 USD to Zimbabwe Parents of Handicapped Children Association (ZPHCA)
description: On November 7, 2021, China donated goods worth $2,300 USD to children with disabilities whose parents are members of the Zimbabwe Parents of Handicapped Children Association (ZIPHCA). The donation consisted of three wheelchairs, mealie-meal, cooking oil, diapers, stationery, sugar, and beans.   Wang Wei, wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, presented the donation at the handover ceremony, stating "The Chinese Embassy has been working with ZPHCA for quite a number of years assisting with goodies whenever we feel that there is a need."
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates supplies worth $2,300 USD to Zimbabwe Parents of Handicapped Children Association (ZPHCA)

# Description
On November 7, 2021, China donated goods worth $2,300 USD to children with disabilities whose parents are members of the Zimbabwe Parents of Handicapped Children Association (ZIPHCA). The donation consisted of three wheelchairs, mealie-meal, cooking oil, diapers, stationery, sugar, and beans.   Wang Wei, wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, presented the donation at the handover ceremony, stating "The Chinese Embassy has been working with ZPHCA for quite a number of years assisting with goodies whenever we feel that there is a need."
justification: Project is a social welfare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of supplies to children with disabilities, social welfare focus
